explanation: To decide if the switch controlling expression (idtype) is invariant under MISRA C, the analyzer needs: (1) the definition of osal_objtype_t (is it an enum, typedef, width, or a const-qualified type?) and the concrete values of every case label (the OS_OBJECT_TYPE_* symbols) to determine whether the parameter can only take a single/constant value or is constrained to an invariant value. (2) The call sites that invoke OS_GetMaxForObjectType (the listed caller functions) so the analyzer can inspect whether any caller ever passes a compile-time constant (literal or macro) or otherwise produces an invariant expression as the idtype argument. Finally, the function declaration/prototype (header) is needed to confirm parameter qualifiers (e.g., const) or attributes that might force invariance. Together these symbols allow checking whether the controlling expression is effectively invariant (forbidden) or genuinely variable (permitted) under the MISRA rule.
